Do you have any other crash logs?

If gtk_init_check() fails, you won't see any workspace selection dialog.  This
happens if the DISPLAY environment variable isn't set or if there is some
other low-level error trying to open an X connection.

I've also run into this problem under Redhat.  I've reproduced the problem with the following steps:

Untar a fresh 3.2M5a
Start eclipse (this works just fine)
Use the update manager to Find and Install from the Callisto update site
Select the Web Tools Platform
Press Select Required
Install all of the new plug-ins
Select Yes to restart the workbench

The following prints to the console:

_X11TransSocketOpen: socket() failed for local
_X11TransSocketOpenCOTSClient: Unable to open socket for local
_X11TransOpen: transport open failed for local/tritium.austin.ibm.com:0

If I owned this bug, I'd be changing it from critical to blocking.
This problem is reproducible with the latest integration build I20060328-0010.  I just realized that this bug was originally opened against 3.1.1.  Should I open a new one to track against 3.2?
Further experimentation revealed that installing the pre-reqs for webtools works just fine.  As soon as you install WST, it fails.  I'll open a new bug against WST.

Bryan, you are seeing bug 106396.

However, gtk_init_check() usually fails because the DISPLAY
environment variable is not set.  The problem in bug 106396
is very strange and specific to IBM JVM versions, along with
(it seems) specific kernel versions, and therefore does not
sound like the original problem reported in this bug.

Timothy, do you still see this problem?  Did you figure out what
was going on?

Using JDK 6.0:

java version "1.6.0"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0-b105)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.6.0-b105, mixed mode, sharing)

and GTK 2.6 on Debian Linux stable we also get this kind of gtk_init failure.
The splash screen appears, then the application stops.

With Ubuntu Dapper Linux we do not see this issue (GTK 2.8).
Which version of eclipse are you using? Do you have a stack trace you can attach?
